{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3229127,"name":"Connor C","username":"Connor-8177","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/connor-8177/{size}/234521_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T18:24:43.944Z","cooked":"

As of right now, this is Vector‚Äôs best funded year. We‚Äôre going into the season with the most money we‚Äôve ever had, and we most likely won‚Äôt have to travel for any competitions or get hotels. With this in mind, we‚Äôre looking at upgrading our tools and shop. The one major tool we‚Äôre missing is a lathe, so I‚Äôve been looking at what lathe to get.

My main question for teams is their opinion on a ‚Äúmini lathe‚Äù (ex 118 pit lathe). We wouldn‚Äôt use our lathe for anything much other then shafts <= 7/8", so it seems excessive to get a full size lathe or a cnc lathe. However, I‚Äôve also heard most mini lathes are low quality and sometimes not worth the extra hassle they create.

What are team‚Äôs thoughts on this, and if your team has had good experiences with a mini lathe, which one would you recommend?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T18:24:43.944Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":969,"reads":344,"readers_count":343,"score":4948.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"Connor C","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50835,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2830m | 8177a"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/1","custom_user_title":"2830m | 8177a","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3229134,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T18:42:55.769Z","cooked":"

With a little TLC and not pushing miniature lathes too far you can get some great results.

Is your use case just canter drilling/tapping shafts (or using a die), cutting groves , trimming to length, etc? Or do you have more advanced plans?

If it is the former, the cheap Harbor Freight lathe will be fine.

The Sherline tools are amazing (I have a mini mill) but ultimately overkill for most FRC shaft applications. You are better off having a better accessorized cheaper lathe (die holder, boring bar, die grinder attachment for keyways (maybe), a good array of center drills, indicators, quality quick change tool post, etc)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T18:48:00.032Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":33,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":310.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=05vUCdzhoe4","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/2","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229135,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T18:43:58.715Z","cooked":"

I like that our team has a lathe. It‚Äôs the best way to teach first principles for machining, to make understanding that transfers to mills and CNC routers. It‚Äôs also really handy for all sorts of little parts.

In my experience using a lathe in FRC, the most important dimension of a lathe is its through-bore capacity. If the hole through the spindle is too small, then you‚Äôll have to cut little pieces of stock for everything you want to make, which creates a lot more waste (and an extra step when making parts). To accommodate 1/2" hex shaft, the through-bore diameter needs to be at least 5/8". If it‚Äôs 3/4" or bigger, then you can also make spacers and bushings. Among most mini lathes that I‚Äôve seen, there are three groups: ~3/8" or 10mm bores, 20mm bores (~0.79"), and ~1.125" bores. I strongly recommend not buying a lathe in the first category!

As far as quality goes, it can be variable. I strongly recommend buying a lathe from a reputable importer, which can provide customer support and warranty replacements. Some USA examples are Little Machine Shop, Grizzly, MicroMark, and Precision Matthews. At 3494‚Äôs previous shop, we had a Weiss lathe, which was quite nice (edit: except that the carriage handwheel was a lie! It was marked as 0.750" per rotation, but was actually something like 0.788"), but the importer it was purchased through has since stopped dealing in lathes.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T19:52:58.396Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":311,"readers_count":310,"score":172.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/3","custom_user_title":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229139,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T18:54:50.155Z","cooked":"

Funny that you mention the Sherline! 3494 has a similar (watchmaker-size, made in USA) Taig lathe, and a 0.79" bore ER40 headstock for it, so it can work long shaft and spacer stock. Without the headstock, the Taig lathe, with a ton of accessories, cost as much as a Harbor Freight mini lathe.

I absolutely love the Taig lathe. It‚Äôs shockingly well-made for the price, very modular, and unintimidating and easy to handle. It has no problems with interrupted cuts on hex shaft and churro, and I‚Äôve even managed to turn D2 tool steel on it without mangling it. The only thing it isn‚Äôt equipped to do is cut threads, but we just use dies in FRC anyway. (And there are many people who‚Äôve published screw-cutting modifications online.) When cleaning chips from the lathe, you can just tip the whole thing over and dump them out! When I have garage space for my personal shop, this it the lathe I‚Äôm getting.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T19:00:33.180Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":273,"readers_count":272,"score":134.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.cartertools.com/catalog.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Taig Detailed Price List with Pictures","clicks":27},{"url":"https://glockcnc.com/store/#!/Sherline-Taig-Lathe-Mill-Headstock-ER40-Spindle-Upgrade/p/50894206/category=8597973","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/4","custom_user_title":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229140,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T18:57:51.476Z","cooked":"

As an aside, one HUGE benefit to the Sherline to some people will be the ability to cut tapers on such a small lathe.

But yes, I would stick to a well regarded cheaper miniature lathe where a lot of other peoples‚Äô experience can help you fine tune the setup. Then have a good selection of accessories for the work you plan to do.

You also bring up a good point. Collet chuck, VERY useful for repeated work (e.g. custom standoffs)

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T18:59:23.740Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":251,"readers_count":250,"score":75.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":41730,"username":"AVHon","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/5","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229142,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T19:02:17.898Z","cooked":"

Our harbor freight lathe continues to serve a role in training, since it‚Äôs so approachable and cute. We also made every shaft on our bots in 2015-2020 with it. They were all 1/2 hex.

I want to finish setting up our benchtop Precision Matthews ~8/10x30/36 (I forget which). I think that‚Äôs a good sweet spot for 98% of FRC parts and newer machinists. And it runs on 120v, which can be important.

We have a 12x42 freestanding lathe on 220v (also a precision Matthews) that is too big for most of our students. The dials land at shoulder level on our 9th graders (and also some of our 12th graders). I can do any FRC part I can imagine, but it‚Äôs actually okay to not have that capability. We haven‚Äôt needed that ‚Äúlast 2%‚Äù in the three years we‚Äôve had it set up. FRC doesn‚Äôt really use steel anymore, which is the only reason to have such a big engine.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T20:41:27.869Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":234,"readers_count":233,"score":151.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229146,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T19:09:14.417Z","cooked":"

I haven‚Äôt yet cut tapers on the Taig, but we do have the option of either the compound slide or the x-adjustable tailstock.

The collet chuck is great. Besides the convenience, it‚Äôs also safer than the 3-jaw chuck. (No chuck key to be vigilant about, and no jagged chuck jaws whirling around.) I‚Äôm thinking about bringing ER40 into our Bridgeport mill too, so students don‚Äôt have to constantly reach for the drawbar.

I‚Äôm also not ready to recommend the Taig to any team looking for a lathe. 3494 has several machining mentors, so working with a quirky machine hasn‚Äôt been a problem. Someday, I may change my mind and do a writeup on how to buy, set up, and run a Taig lathe for FRC (and maybe even FTC) use. The size, weight, quality, and price definitely set it and the Sherline apart from every other lathe out there.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-04T05:39:46.658Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":224,"readers_count":223,"score":49.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/7","custom_user_title":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229150,"name":"E L","username":"e172","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/e172/{size}/256379_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T19:20:48.273Z","cooked":"

we have a tiny lathe and the thing is awesome

IMG_31901920√ó1440 288 KB

we use it mainly for manufacturing and tuning smaller axles and things, we also have a 1/4 size milling machine that is mounted to one of our toolboxes that other teams can use at events

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T19:20:48.273Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":207,"readers_count":206,"score":136.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"E L","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/5/2/5263b9adc0fb3666d25d6b9fda6ee99f32bc7e47.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49402,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è She/Her | Opinions are my own"},"user_suspended":true,"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/8","custom_user_title":"üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è She/Her | Opinions are my own","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229154,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T19:25:30.044Z","cooked":"

I was shopping for a mini-lathe or benchtop lathe a year ago, with these requirements:

  • Must be <$3,000
  • Available new through a conventional, reputable retailer (not AliExpress, Facebook, etc.)
  • Must have through-bore diameter >= 0.7 inches (enough to accommodate spacer stock)
  • Must have a swing of at least 3 inches (big enough to turn gears and hex hubs)
  • Must have at least 9 inches between centers (enough to accommodate the longest gearbox shaft), including workholding (so, with a chuck, more like 11 or 12 inches between centers)
  • Must have at least 500 watts of drive power; strong preference for brushless motor
  • Must have an overall width <= 48 inches
  • Must run on 120V single-phase <12A
  • Handwheel measurements must match the actual travel
  • Must not have plastic gears in the spindle drive

Besides the Sherline and Taig micro-lathes I‚Äôve been gushing about, here are the more conventional candidates I found:

  • Precision Matthews PM-1022V
  • LittleMachineShop HiTorque 7x16 except that the compound slide and cross slide leadscrews are 1mm pitch but the handwheels are labelled 0.040" (an error of ~2%), and metal change gears are an optional extra over the ABS plastic gears. These may be acceptable to most FRC users.
  • LittleMachineShop HiTorque 8.5x20
  • Grizzly G4000
  • Grizzly G0765 except that it‚Äôs powered by a 3/4 HP brushed DC motor
  • Grizzly G0768 and G0768Z (which has a DRO) except that they‚Äôre powered by a 3/4 HP brushed DC motor
  • MicroMark MicroLux 7 x 16 Mini Lathe or 7 x 16 Hotrod Lathe

Of all of those, the three 7x16 lathes are the only ones that are really ‚Äúmini‚Äù lathes. The others are more conventionally benchtop-sized, but still quite reasonable for a team to purchase, ship, receive, and set up in their shop.

Hex Aluminum Spacer Stock - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/9","custom_user_title":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229163,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T19:43:53.093Z","cooked":"

Vent:

  • Handwheel measurements must match the actual travel

This was a real bear of a requirement. For many lathes, like the LittleMachineShop HiTorque 7x16, the only way to actually find out was to download and read through the manual. The product listings either don‚Äôt say anything at all about handwheel travel (which is the case for the LMS lathe), or (on some other retailers) the product page lies and says that the travel is in inches, but the manual clarifies that it‚Äôs only an approximation of the actual travel in millimeters! The only things you can trust are when the handwheels are marked in millimeters (which I could deal with but would be uncomfortable in our otherwise all-inch shop), or, like the MicroMark lathe, when they go out of their way to assure you that they‚Äôve replaced all of the metric racks and leadscrews with ‚Äútrue inch‚Äù hardware.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T21:00:20.578Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":115.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"Rich Jr","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.precisionmatthews.com/shop/pm-1130v-lathe/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PM-1130V 11‚Ä≥x30‚Ä≥ Precision Lathe ‚Äì Precision Matthews Machinery Co.","clicks":25},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/7/3/737ae1b7d7002c4758606f89cdb731d1a2c73166.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6998,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/11","custom_user_title":"FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229172,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-03T19:57:48.913Z","cooked":"

We had a grizzly G0752 for years and it worked well but we had to do a lot of work on it to make it functional for student use, quick change tool post, etc. (We still have it and use it sometimes).

The Precision Mathews machines are so much better than any of the grizzly or other hobbyist/mini machines I have used or seen. They come with all the features you will probably want to add at some point to the cheaper lathes you can buy. DRO, cam lock tailstock, power feeds, etc. Also once you have a lathe and start using it, a lot more tasks become tasks you can do or parts you can make on the lathe than before you have one.

Assuming you are planning to be an FRC team for many years, if at all possible buy the lathe your program will want in 5-10 years now instead of spending time and money on something cheaper that the team will replace later.

We have rarely/never wished we had anything bigger than our 10x20-30in lathes that we have, they are bigger than mini lathes but still approachable and useable by students. The spindles bores are big enough for most FRC tasks and the bearings are large enough that if you have to use it as a press (which you shouldn‚Äôt but sometimes it‚Äôs the only way), etc you won‚Äôt damage it immediately.

Team 3673 has a Grizzly lathe and we use it all the time! it is one of our most used tools.
We use it to make spacers out of plastic, and aluminum, make precise bearing holes, etc.
There are so many uses for a lathe and the mini lathe is a great cheap entry-level tool that allows for a great start into this. If you can get one with a mill attachment or the attachment that you can buy later on, that‚Äôs a great option and something to seriously consider when you are looking for one.
100% get the lathe!

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2023-09-03T23:06:58.580Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":130,"readers_count":129,"score":91.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":440446,"topic_slug":"lathe-mini-or-not","display_username":"jedgar6","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/f/f/ffd7abc479aefb7df6ea83c009d91cf43dbebb6a.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33848,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9410"},"post_url":"/t/lathe-mini-or-not/440446/19","custom_user_title":"9410","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229284,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-04T05:47:05.915Z","cooked":"

I used to use a 7x10 on 1072 to tap thunderhex and cut spacers/shafts to size. They replaced it with a new one somewhat recently, and strangely, the motor does not have enough torque to tap 1/4"-20 on its own anymore.

I would recommend any 7x12 mini lathe. The 7x10 lathes are actually 7x8, so you will pay only slightly more for 4" extra to play with - handy for keeping your tailsstock mounted all the time and moving parts around. A 3 jaw chuck will handle hex shafts and spacers just fine. I have found that 1/2" hex collets can be very hit or miss on the fit, so get a good collet brand like Maritool if you go the collet chuck route. The chuck itself can be any brand, for the tolerances we need to hold.

If you want to round the ends of hex shafts for gearboxes, then you may want to invest in a larger used lathe or higher-quality mini lathe like a Microlux, along with a collet chuck or 6-jaw chuck. You can also just grind down the jaws of the 3-jaw square occasionally, but that‚Äôs a pain, even if it gets you within 0.001" on the concentricity. It‚Äôs also worth looking at some softjaws for the same reason.

If you get a cutoff tool, The carbide insert ones can work fine, just make sure to have a good stock of inserts. HSS cutoff bars are better but are weirdly pricey? If you get a 0.04" wide one that can be good for circlips.

No matter what you go with, get a quick change tool post, preferably a wedge-type one.
